bioghist.p: Born in 1895 to Samuel Frederic and Edith Altee Corlies Houston, Henry Howard Houston II (1895-1918), nicknamed "Hennie," was the last of the couple's three children, and their only son. Henry graduated from the University of Pennsylvania in 1916, and in June of that year enlisted in Battery "C" of the 1st Pennsylvania Artillery. He went with his unit to the Mexican border when President Wilson called for troops to respond to Pancho Villa's raids into the United States. Along with his cousin, Henry Howard Houston Woodward, Hennie served in France with the American Ambulance Service (later, American Field Service). When the United States entered the hostilities in Europe, Hennie rejoined his fellow Pennsylvanians in the 53rd Field Artillery Brigade of the American Expeditionary Force, and served as aide-de-camp for Brigadier General William G. Price, Jr. Both Henry Houston II and Henry H. H. Woodward were killed in France in 1918. Hennie died in the village of Arcis-le-Ponsart (Department of the Marne) on 18 August, a short time after being struck by fragments from an exploding artillery shell.

scopecontent.p: The collection contains correspondence, diaries, newspaper and magazine clippings, and photographs and prints of Henry H. Houston II.
